body:
### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.9.0-dev-470+g50ffb8d7f4

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

Yes (9.0.0910)

### Operating system/version

Arch GNU/Linux

### Terminal name/version

foot `foot version: 1.13.1 +pgo +ime +graphemes -assertions`

### $TERM environment variable

foot

### Installation

AUR

### How to reproduce the issue
1. `nvim--clean`
1. `:terminal`
1. Confirm the output of `tput lines` is less than 10.
1. Inside the terminal do `echo "hello"; clear`.
1. Scroll up to confirm that clearing works. (in vim, use `C-w` `N` then navigate in normal mode)
1. Echo something longer than 10 lines. In fish: `for i in (seq 0 20); echo $i; end; clear`.
1. Scroll up again and see the output of the last command.

### Expected behavior

Terminal gets cleared every time.

### Actual behavior

The output from every single command before (maybe with some of it cut off or corrupted in some way) remains.

[recording.webm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/77174844/207610703-57f60cd0-c8b4-42b5-acc5-1a03a9306ce4.webm)

### Extra information

I had a conversation with someone else as I was troubleshooting, and they recommended I report the issue here. I believe the relevant line is [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/d311c5481dede47d752fa39cb00d728ba18ef5bc/src/nvim/terminal.c#L163). Something about not being able to handle `.sb_clear` or `ED3`.

comment_data.body: I'll keep iterating on the instructions to reproduce the bug to simplify testing.

Why is this annoying? Often when I'm debugging, I use `cargo watch` to get the output of println debugging. When I do `gg` to get to the top (custom config), I'm moved to an output of a previous iteration which I don't care about.

This doesn't only happen in Neovim within [`foot`](https://codeberg.org/dnkl/foot), it also happens with Neovide and Alacritty.
Just `printf '\x1b[3J'` to reproduce
Hmm, pangoterm doesn't implement this either?

> Just `printf '\x1b[3J'`

Not sure how this is supposed to help.
Even so, it has no effect. (Notice the duplicate "Compiling"/"Finished" messages at the top.)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/77174844/207604252-f81cc87b-ba64-4ca3-b3b7-89440c85d6fe.png)

Even when I type the clear command, I can still scroll back to previous outputs. Is this standard behavior?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/77174844/207604489-df23c95f-3d1d-4add-b010-a20f98197b39.png)
I mean to reproduce
I updated the repro instructions to something much simpler.
In my experience, that's how all terminal emulators work. Scroll back buffer is not deleted by `clear`. Kitty has explicit command to trash it, but that's not standard.
If this is standard/expected behavior, this sucks.
I have PR #21412 that seems to fix this, but it sometimes behaves strangely and doesn't seem to work on Windows.

Kitty's special clear clears everything, even current prompt. I don't see it as a big deal especially for "tailing" commands. Maybe it would be simplest solution for Neovim also - just erase everything in the buffer using single command.

Thinking about it more, `clear` should not ever delete scroll back. It just emits ansi sequence, which anything can do. Therefore anything could mask what it did, which stinks.

So my take on this would be Neovim command to erase it. Something like `:TermClear` or whatever.
What the hell is the point of `clear` if it still allows you to scroll back? @vlada-dudr
It usually works by scrolling down and pretending there is nothing above the first line until user scrolls up.

By the way it looks like you can emulate deleting scroll back buffer by `set scrollback=1` and resetting it back after. For some reason the option doesn't accept 0.

Terminal is effectively composed of two parts - screen and scrollback. Clear only works with screen part. So clear is basically "send everything to scrollback". Point is that when applications want to use whole screen, they can ensure there is no garbage on their workspace.

By the way proof of concept works like this:
```lua
local term_clear = function()
  vim.fn.feedkeys(" ^L", 'n')
  local sb = vim.bo.scrollback
  vim.bo.scrollback = 1
  vim.bo.scrollback = sb
end

vim.keymap.set('t', '<C-l>', term_clear)
```
Which repurposes Ctrl-L (which most shells bind to clear) by sending Ctrl-L to terminal program and truncates scrollback by setting it to 1 and resets in back afterwards.

BTW, copy paste likely won't work, one should replace ^L with the real thing by typing Ctrl-V and Ctrl-L which inserts exactly the sequence to send.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/4413 would open the door for custom handling of `clear` and other terminal requests.
You can clear with ^L but there's still the last scrollback line to deal with - OCD screams... :(

From <https://invisible-island.net/xterm/ctlseqs/ctlseqs.html>:
> Ps = 3  â‡’  Selective Erase Saved Lines, xterm.
Closing in favor of #34087

title: :terminal "clear" should clear scrollback, not just the screen
